docs.snippet: Media | Newspapers doomed? So what? Richard Posner writes that "long after newspapers like the New York Times and the Washington Post have ceased print publication, their Web sites may be among the leading Internet news services." He reasons that ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Media | Newspapers doomed? So what? Richard Posner writes that "long after newspapers like the New York Times and the Washington Post have ceased print publication, their Web sites may be among the leading Internet news services." He reasons that aggregation sites like Google News are "parasitic on print newspapers' large staffs of reporters." Something has to fill the void of print, or the Internet will kill "the goose that lays the golden egg." -- Becker-Posner Blog

headline.main: Ink-Stained No More

docs.abstract: Media | Newspapers doomed? So what? He reasons that aggregation sites like Google News are "parasitic on print newspapers' large staffs of reporters." Something [...]

It may be time for Internet companies and Congress to look more closely at setting specific rules governing those records.

docs.snippet: This just in from the Dept. of Unintended Consequences: among the many, many pieces of e-mail I received about my column about Google's day-care woes last week were several from parents who had children in other day-care centers in Silicon Valley,...
docs.lead_paragraph: This just in from the Dept. of Unintended Consequences: among the many, many pieces of e-mail I received about my column about Google's day-care woes last week were several from parents who had children in other day-care centers in Silicon Valley, particularly the small handful that use the Reggio Emilia philosophy. Apparently, when Google was preparing to open its ultra-fancy center, The Woods, it aggressively recruited Reggio Emilia-trained day-care teachers from all over the Bay Area. It lured them with much higher salaries and the prospect of being full-fledged Google employees - status that more than a few Google engineers can't claim.

docs.snippet: ''Cloud computing'' is a white-hot buzzword these days. It basically means working with files and programs that reside on the Internet, beyond your company's walls -- out there in the ''cloud.''      Everyday consumers are doing cloud computing, t...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Cloud computing'' is a white-hot buzzword these days. It basically means working with files and programs that reside on the Internet, beyond your company's walls -- out there in the ''cloud.'' Everyday consumers are doing cloud computing, too, maybe without even realizing it. When you use an Internet-based backup service, or Google's online word processor or spreadsheet, or a Gmail or Yahoo mail account, you're working with data on a secure Internet server somewhere -- not on your hard drive.

headline.main: In Sync To Pierce The Cloud

docs.abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on Apple's new MobileMe service, overhaul of suite of Internet features that used to be called .Mac; says service, priced at $100 a year, is meant to keep e-mail, calendars, address books and Web bookmarks on all computers--Mac, Windows Pcs, iPhones and iPod Touches--synchronized in real time; service is known as 'cloud computing,' meaning working with files and programs that reside on Internet, beyond company's walls--out there in the 'cloud'; drawing; photo (M)

headline.main: A Truce for Yahoo, but the War May Not Be Over

docs.abstract: With key shareholders choosing not to support his plan to unseat Yahoo's board, Carl C. Icahn has backed down and agreed to accept three board seats as a compromise. Yahoo will most likely try to stabilize its operations, get its ad deal with Google approved, rethink Jerry Yang as chief executive and wait for Microsoft to decide whether to make a renewed offer to buy the company.

docs.snippet: Goodmail Systems now has deals to pay most big Internet and Webmail providers to deliver messages from its clients without subjecting them to the dreaded spam filter. In return for first class delivery, Goodmail pays the e-mail companies a big par...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago I wrote about Goodmail Systems, a company that wants to help big companies make sure that e-mail they send doesn't wind up trapped in a spam filter. Their idea is to charge the sender and give most of the money to the Internet providers and Web e-mail companies (like Google or Yahoo) to assure safe passage for paying messages.

headline.main: Goodmail Is Back Trying to Sell Access to Your In-Box

docs.abstract: Goodmail Systems now has deals to pay most big Internet and Webmail providers to deliver messages from its clients without subjecting them to the dreaded spam filter. In return for first class delivery, Goodmail pays the e-mail companies a big part of its fees. Does this two-tier system violate the ideas of network neutrality?

docs.snippet: Google is showing users how it takes data from their history of searches and their location to customize the results it displays. So far it is not displaying similar information about data it uses to target advertising....
docs.lead_paragraph: Many things are scarier when they are in the shadows. This is especially true when it comes to the ways big companies gather and use data about us.

docs.lead_paragraph: Google has long invested in promising start-ups. So the news that the company was thinking about formalizing those efforts by creating a venture-capital arm, reported in The Wall Street Journal Thursday, was hardly surprising.
